descriptions.content:
Verbs of movement are often formed by using directional auxiliaries that specify whether an action is coming toward or going away from the speaker (or the point of reference).

  • ཁོང་མཆོང་ཡོང་གིས། “He’s coming jumping.” (He’s jumping this way.)
  • ཁོང་མཆོང་འགྲོ་གིས། “He’s going jumping.” (He’s jumping away.)
  • ང་ནང་ལ་ལོག་འགྲོ་གི་ཡིན། “I’m going back home (away from the interlocutor).”
  • ང་ནང་ལ་ལོག་ཡོང་གི་ཡིན། “I’m coming back home (toward the interlocutor).”

The two auxiliaries may also be used with non-volitional verbs to indicate the beginning of a process (inchoative sense). The auxiliary ཡོང་ is used with the first person (singular or plural), whereas འགྲོ་ is used with the second and third persons (singular or plural).

  • ང་གཉིད་ཁུག་ཡོང་གིས། “I’m starting to fall asleep.”
  • ཁོང་གཉིད་ཁུག་འགྲོ་གིས། “He’s starting to fall asleep.”
  • ང་འཁྱག་ཡོང་གིས། “I’m starting to feel cold.”
  • ཁོང་འཁྱག་འགྲོ་གིས། “He’s starting to feel cold.”
